title: Each year, millions of Americans fail to appear in court for low-level offenses, & arrest warrants are issued. Text message reminders and a redesigned summons form reduced NYC failure to appear by 13-21% and lead to 30,000 fewer arrest warrants over a 3-year period.

In 2009, Colorado started a program to offer long-acting reversible contraceptives (e.g. IUDs) to low-income women. The initiative reduced births by approximately 20% among 15–19 year olds who lived near the clinics that were funded to offer IUDs.
New study shows the best way to express gratitude: People who help you love to hear how their kind actions met your needs. They are less impressed when you acknowledge how costly their action was.

First-of-its-kind global survey shows the initial phase of the COVID-19 lockdown dramatically altered our personal habits. Overall, healthy eating increased because we ate out less frequently. However, we snacked more. We got less exercise. We went to bed later and slept more poorly
Amid pandemic, U.S. has seen 300,000 ‘excess deaths,’ with highest rates among people of color

Achieving universal mask use (95% mask use in public) could save an additional 129,574 lives in the US from September 22, 2020 through the end of February 2021, or an additional 95,814 lives assuming a lesser adoption of mask wearing (85%).

Researchers have discovered a new mechanism by which clumps of tau protein are created in the brain, killing brain cells and causing Alzheimer's disease. Getting to grips with mechanisms like this may lead to breakthrough treatments.

71.5% of people reported that they would be very or somewhat likely to take a COVID-19 vaccine (n=13,426 from 19 countries), from almost 90% in China to less than 55% in Russia. Those reporting higher levels of trust in information from government sources were more likely to accept a vaccine.

A new electron microscope provides "unprecedented structural detail," allowing scientists to "visualize individual atoms in a protein, see density for hydrogen atoms, and image single-atom chemical modifications."

Humans are born with brains ‘prewired’ to see words, study finds. Brain scans of newborns showed a part of the visual cortex was connected to the language network of the brain, even before any exposure to language.

People who take microdoses of psychedelic drugs consistently report that it results in improved mood and creativity, while having few side effects, according to new research published in the Journal of Psychopharmacology.

Anti-vaxxers have rebranded: Vaccine opponents have shifted their messaging toward the promotion of civil liberties. Between 2009 to 2019, conversations around civil liberties in the anti-vaccine community had increased, with Facebook pages framing vaccines as an issue of values and civil rights.

Maya people at the ancient city of Tikal in Guatemala used a mineral called zeolite to decontaminate drinking water in one of their large reservoirs. It's the oldest known example of water purification in the Western Hemisphere.
Study: Men are more likely than women to perceive face masks as infringing on their freedom

Mouthwashes, oral rinses may inactivate human coronaviruses. Several of the nasal and oral rinses had a strong ability to neutralize human coronavirus, which suggests that these products may have the potential to reduce the amount of virus spread by people who are COVID-19-positive

Growth rate of adult trees is linked to fungal networks colonizing their roots.When they colonize the roots of a tree, fungal networks act as a sort of highway, allowing water, nutrients and even the compounds that send defence signals against insect attacks to flow back and forth among the trees.
Superwhite paint can cool buildings even in hot sunlight
Low doses of LSD (5 - 10 micrograms) demonstrated selective, beneficial effects on mood and cognition in a placebo-controlled, crossover trial (N=24)

Using artificial intelligence and machine learning, scientists have developed a sensor that can neutralise a star's 'twinkle' caused by heat variations in the Earth's atmosphere. This will make the discovery and study of planets in distant solar systems easier from optical telescopes on Earth.
Down syndrome associated with 10-fold increased risk for COVID-19 mortality
Higher consumption of green tea and coffee was associated with reduced all-cause mortality: their combined effect appeared to be additive in patients with type 2 diabetes (n=4,923).

Newborn brains lack maturity to process emotions as adults do, study finds. Brain scans reveal humans aren’t born with brain circuitry that attaches emotions to the things they see or hear in their environment.
Neuroscientists discover a molecular mechanism that allows memories to form
Study: Cannabis Strain Names Give False Sense of Diversity
The link between education and support for climate change is weaker among right-wing ideologists in developed countries

Cannabis reduces OCD symptoms by half in the short-term: People with obsessive-compulsive disorder, or OCD, report that the severity of their symptoms was reduced by about half within four hours of smoking cannabis, according to a recent study
Voyager Spacecraft Detect an Increase in The Density of Space Outside The Solar System
Fewer than 4% of people in Wuhan have COVID-19 antibodies, study finds

Extroverts are least likely to follow official guidance to stay at home during COVID-19 lockdowns, finds new study of over 101,000 people in 55 countries. However, people with agreeableness, neuroticism or conscientiousness personality traits tend to stay at home when advised to do so.

Virus-mimicking drug helps immune system target cunning cancer cells: Researchers have found that a drug that activates the body's natural defenses by behaving like a virus may also make certain stealthy melanoma tumors visible to the immune system

Astrophysicists have devised a way to use the shadow of a supermassive black hole to test and rule out novel theories of gravity. The shape of the first black hole image provides the most precise match yet to certain predictions from general relativity, researchers report.

The biggest mass extinction event in Earth’s history was caused by a volcanic eruption in Siberia that spewed carbon dioxide (CO2) into the atmosphere. The Permian–Triassic extinction event, also known as the ‘Great Dying’, wiped out 95% of marine species and 70% of terrestrial species at the time.
New algorithm maps and prioritizes most benifitial targets to restore earth's ecosystems. To mitigate climate change and biodiversity loss.
Survey experiments show that white Americans become substantially less supportive of gun availability when they are primed to think of black men rather than whites and women.

Glaciers are stable or growing in a region north-west of the Tibetan Plateau because of low temperature sensitivities and an increase in snowfall caused by increases in evapotranspiration from irrigated agriculture.
Scientists use 3D printing to reinforce concrete with polymer lattices, creating more durable building materials with a lower carbon footprint

A new OLED display can achieve more than 10,000 pixels per inch, which might lead to advanced virtual reality and augmented reality displays, researchers say. In the future, metasurfaces might also find use trapping light in applications such as solar cells and light sensors.

A team based in Japan has proposed a method to use time crystals to simulate massive networks with very little computing power. The quantum nature of time crystals can be used to simulate large, specialized networks, such as communication systems or artificial intelligence.

Premature infants born earlier than 28 weeks gestation who experience fewer needle pokes while receiving life-saving care in the neonatal intensive care unit may have better growth of a part of the brain called the thalamus.

Study: Social isolation exacerbates the situation of school bullying victims. The results emphasize that fostering a friendly atmosphere among children in the classroom, as well as promoting the development of social, moral and emotional competences, are key to preventing school bullying.

Mental health problems such as PTSD anxiety and depression are common among healthcare staff during and immediately after pandemics. Almost a quarter of health-care workers (23.4 per cent) experienced PTSD symptoms during the most intense 'acute' phase of previous pandemic outbreaks

How your behaviour in childhood predicts whether you’ll be in a relationship as an adult: A new study suggests that the seeds of future partnering patterns are planted early and are visible even before adolescence. This has important implications for children with behavioural difficulties
Scientists create an artificial intelligence model of cancer cells, allowing them to predict if a particular treatment will work and know the reasons why it does or does not
Near-uncrushable beetle's exoskeleton could inspire tough structures

It is possible to predict future onset of Alzheimer's disease using language samples obtained from cognitively normal individuals. Significant predictive power was obtained, with AUC of 0.74 and accuracy of 0.70. The mean time to diagnosis of mild AD was 7.59 years.
A blend of racial prejudice, poor coping and partisan media viewing were found in Americans who stigmatized people of Asian descent during the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a new study.
Water could be extracted from desert air using heat from sunlight

Air pollution was significantly associated with an increased risk of hospital admissions for several neurological disorders, including Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and other dementias, in a long-term study of more than 63 million older U.S. adults, led by researchers at Harvard.

How early Homo sapiens responded to climate change reveals a "hallmark" of our species. Analysis of a drilled core representing 1 million years of environmental history suggests a major transition in ancient tool tech was prompted by adaptation to environmental threats.

Researchers have found that dairy was being produced as far back as 2500 BCE by using molecular analysis techniques to study residues from ancient pottery. It is the earliest known dairy production in India and could have helped produce the type of food surplus needed for trade.
The human body contains "previously unnoticed" salivary glands behind the nose, near the center of the head.
Your "cough cloud" is 7 to 23 times larger when you're not wearing a mask

A potential therapy for treating COVID-19 has been identified after researchers blocked the virus from the receptor neuropilin-1 (NRP1), a previously unknown avenue for COVID-19 to bind and enter cells.
The arthritis drug tocilizumab doesn’t appear to help fight COVID-19
Extrachromosomal DNA loops enable tumor cells to resist anti-cancer drugs
Men who feel their partners have less power in their relationships than they do report lower relationship quality
A new study failed to replicate Carol's Dweck's pillar work on fixed vs growth mindset in college students, even when comparing at-risk populations.
Plastic baby bottles shed millions of microplastics when shaken

Math ability might have deeper, biological roots - Scientists in Germany argue that about one-fifth of math ability in children could be explained by differences in grey matter volume. Those differences were tied to variations in a gene called ROBO1. (n=77 and n=101)

Scientists mapped genome of a saber-toothed cat species named Homotherium for the first time. The cat’s genes reveal that it was a highly skilled pack hunter that could pursue its prey over vast distances. Homotheriums lived on five continents and roamed for millions of years before it went extinct.

Residents of U.S. counties with more social connections (measured as Facebook friends) to China or Italy - the first countries to report major COVID-19 outbreaks - were more likely to adhere to social distancing restrictions at the onset of the pandemic, according to a new study.

Responses to COVID-19 Stay-Home Orders. Americans strongly reduced their visits to grocery stores, pharmacies, and transit stations following stay-at-home orders from mayors and governors earlier this year, but did not reduce their visits to parks and beaches
High levels of microplastics released from infant feeding bottles during formula preparation.

A study of online forums dedicated to infidelity finds that those forums are often used to promote intimate partner surveillance (IPS). Perpetrators share technical strategies, and seek validation of their abuse.
Higher consumption of green tea and coffee is associated with reduced all-cause mortality in those with diabetes.
Binge Drinking Causes Liver Damage by Reducing Cellular Levels of NAD+
Researchers find that the brain overvalues the ending of experience rather than accurately summarizing the value of the total experience — a cognitive bias that worsens decision-making.

Researchers have succeeded in terahertz imaging of early-stage breast cancer less than 0.5 mm without staining, which is difficult to identify even by pathological diagnosis. Their work provides a breakthrough towards rapid and precise on-site diagnosis of various types of cancer.

Sanctuary city policies reduced deportations of individuals without criminal records by half, but had no impact on deportations of individuals with violent criminal records. Contrary to the rhetoric of opponents of sanctuary cities, sanctuary city policies had no impact on crime rates.

Climate change pushes species distribution areas northward where species face e.g. habitat degradation. A new study suggests that protected areas can help wintering waterbirds adapt to climate change by advancing their northward range shifts. The shifts were over 40% faster inside protected areas.

Strontium, oxygen, and carbon isotopes were measured in human tooth enamel from 66 burials in two different residential groups at the Classic Maya site of Copan in western Honduras. Nearly 50% of the individuals were identified as non-local based these isotopes.

Artificial intelligence reveals 1.8 billion individual trees in the Sahara. The data suggest that it will soon be possible, with certain limitations, to map the location and size of every tree worldwide.
Using next generation sequencing on SARS-CoV-2 will help accurately diagnose the novel coronavirus, identify mutations and track its history.
Some male fish use their tails to fan rivals’ sperm away from eggs
Liberal's and Conservative's brains fire differently when presented with controversial political issues, suggesting a neural basis for partisan biases
Soil fungi act like a support network for trees, study shows
Our Milky Way galaxy has a ‘clumpy halo’ surrounding it
Scientists measure the shortest amount of time ever: A zeptosecond

In a new study published in Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry shows that children rated by their elementary schoolteachers as being anxious or inattentive were more likely to remain unpartnered from age 18 to 35 years.

Having higher levels of physical fitness - measured up to 4 years prior to pandemic - is associated with lower risk of hospitalisation when these people happened to get Coronavirus. (Maximal Exercise Capacity is Inversely Related to Hospitalization Secondary to Coronavirus Disease 2019)

The cemi (conscious electromagnetic information) theory of consciousness: a new theory which posits that consciousness is a result of the temporal integration of information in the brain’s electromagnetic field

A phenomenon of quantum mechanics known as superposition can impact timekeeping in high-precision clocks. The research takes into account quantum effects beyond Albert Einstein’s theory of relativity to make a new prediction about the nature of time.
Evidence of dairy production in the Indus Valley Civilization
Scientists make digital breakthrough in chemistry that could revolutionize the drug industry
PLACID Trial: Convalescent plasma is ineffective for Covid-19 ( academic comment, BMJ)
Both Right- and Left-Wing Authoritarianism are linked to support for punitive coronavirus measures
Those funky cheese smells allow microbes to “talk” to and feed each other: Researchers discover that bacteria that ripen cheese respond to the volatile gases produced by cheese fungi
New study highlights the role of cultural variations in the link between religion and prejudice

That Fake News You Read May Help You Remember Even More: People who receive reminders of past misinformation may form new factual memories with greater fidelity, according to a recent article that included two experiments (Ns = 96)
Robot that can perform colonoscopies aims to make it less unpleasant
Colorado River drought can be predicted by warming in the ocean
A Concept of a Compact and Inexpensive Device for Controlling Weeds with Laser Beams
Mice show paternal behavior after siring, but rats do not. New research shows that extra dopamine in rat brains suppresses paternal behavior in fathers

Notable similarities between monkeys, apes, and humans indicate that nonadjacent dependency processing, a crucial cognitive facilitator of language, is an ancestral trait that evolved at least 40 million years before language itself
A short sequence in the genome of the virus that causes COVID-19 provides it with an additional way to enter our cells, possibly leading to maximum infectious potential.
Researchers develop method for earlier detection of Alzheimer’s disease
Office workers in China are more likely to order food delivery than go out for lunch when the air is bad outside. This in turn increases plastic waste from food packaging.
Diabolical Ironclad Beetle's 'armor' gives clues to tougher planes
First use of artificial canopy bridge by the world’s most critically endangered primate the Hainan gibbon Nomascus hainanus (only 30 individuals remain)
As Plain as the Nose on Your Face: The Case for A Nasal (Mucosal) Route of Vaccine Administration for Covid-19 Disease Prevention

The manipulation of online images. The study was driven by the increased prevalence of fake news and how social media platforms and news organisations are struggling to identify and combat visual mis/disinformation presented to their audiences.
A quick Chest X-ray of COVID-19 patients predicts time to critical illness, independent of underlying conditions
Quantum Time Twist Offers a Way to Create Schrödinger's Clock - Scientific American
New Record For The Shortest Time Span Measured: Zeptoseconds
Homo erectus, not humans, may have invented the barbed bone point
Genome sequencing shows northern and southern climate barriers to the spread of Africanized bees
People From Japan May Be Less Prone Than Americans To Some Of The Harmful Health-Related Effects Of Negative Emotions
Study of 256 couples finds that men prefer risky behaviors more than their partners do, and relationship length was associated with a decline in women’s preference for their partner’s risk-taking.

Research response to COVID-19 needed better coordination and collaboration. Trials are mainly single-centered, open-labeled and have relatively small sample size. There is a notable redundancy in research questions.
Mitigating a COVID-19 Outbreak Among Major League Baseball Players — United States, 2020
The Moon's ancient magnetic field helped protect the young Earth
Re-analysis of the 267-GHz ALMA observations of Venus: No statistically significant detection of phosphine

Despite more of the population staying at home as government policies on COVID-19 become stricter, a study has found that a person’s personality influences how likely they are to stay at home during the pandemic - and cannot be entirely overridden.

US donors are inclined to give less generously to charities in developing countries when they believe those funds will help people with darker skin. Donors who harbored more implicit bias against darker skin were less likely to give more than $10 to the charity than those who were less prejudiced.
A country level analysis measuring the impact of government actions, country preparedness and socioeconomic factors on COVID-19 mortality and related health outcomes
Subtle seizures often go unrecognized for years prior to diagnosis, with serious consequences
Interdisciplinary study bridges sociology and geography to ask what motivates tropical deforestation versus conservation on Brazilian farms
Why bat scientists are socially distancing from their subjects
Reversal of aging with epigenetic reprogramming, a therapy that can rejuvenate multiple organs/tissues in progeroid mice, improves memory in naturally aged mice

Young adults face higher risk of severe disease from infections than school-age children: New research suggests children aged 5-14 years are most resilient to infectious diseases, and immune aging may start in young adults, with implications for drug and vaccine design
Happiness and the evolution of brain size: Serotonin can act as a growth factor for the stem cells in the fetal human brain that determine brain size
Maximal Exercise Capacity is Inversely Related to Hospitalization Secondary to Coronavirus Disease 2019
new research about relation between depression and social media use: "Depression alters the circadian pattern of online activity"
Women are more likely than men to say they have a best friend
Microplastic release from the degradation of polypropylene feeding bottles during infant formula preparation
Hypnosis Experts Cast Doubt on Famous Psychological Experiments
Safety and efficacy of COVID‐19 convalescent plasma in severe pulmonary disease: A report of 17 patients
Three-dimensional electron-hole superfluidity in a superlattice close to room temperature
Hot-button words trigger conservatives and liberals differently
Octopus-inspired sucker transfers thin, delicate tissue grafts and biosensors
Effects of Aging and Lifelong Aerobic Exercise on Basal and Exercise-Induced Inflammation in Women
NAD+ Binds to and Inhibits a Protein that Promotes Degeneration of Neurons
Two Studies Show COVID-19 Antibodies Persist for Months
Solving the Problem of Slippery Train Tracks Due to Fallen Leaves
Microplastics in take-out food containers
Important to address the risk factors to reduce the burden of diseases, nationally, regionally, and globally.
The Subdivision of NAD+ into Cell Compartments is Critical to Mammalian Life

Scientists find that seismic ripples in the surface of the sun, dubbed sunquakes, are associated with solar flares. The researchers hope the discovery will lead to accurate predictions of the timing and intensity of future solar flares.
Tetrahedra may explain water's uniqueness
In collaboration with Pfizer, IBM scientists have developed a potential AI model that could help predict Alzheimer’s disease’s before it develops.

A bioarchaeological study of African American health and mortality in the post-emancipation U.S. south found that whereas urban adults had higher midlife mortality and reduced longevity compared to their rural counterparts, both rural and urban children experienced poor health.
Changing diets and traditional lifestyle of Siberian Arctic Indigenous Peoples and effects on health and well-being

Interactions of DNA and proteins have deep-seated propensities to form higher-ordered structures such as those which allow the extreme packaging of DNA in cells. This new understanding of biopolymeric self-organisation may be important for understanding how life self-organised to become living.
Pilot study: Inflammatory Biomarkers be Used to Spot Respiratory Viral Infections

Cellular optogenetics uses light to control cell signaling in space and time, making it an invaluable technique for disease research. Scientists developed a way to make these tools much easier to monitor and apply, and demonstrated their use in studying cellular side effects of cancer medicines.
Forelimb force direction and magnitude independently controlled by spinal modules in the macaque
NASA’s OSIRIS-REx spacecraft lands on asteroid in bid to collect samples
Interacting Infrastructure Disruptions Due to Environmental Events and Long‐Term Climate Change
Language prediction mechanisms in human auditory cortex
Catalytic upcycling of high-density polyethylene via a processive mechanism
No Evidence That Salt Water Ingestion Kills Adult Mosquitoes (Diptera: Culicidae)
Agency in the fentanyl era: Exploring the utility of fentanyl test strips in an opaque drug market
Estimation of change in house sales prices in the United States after heat pump adoption
Cross‐sectional biomarker comparisons in asthma monitoring using a longitudinal design: The eNose premise
HSB-1/HSF-1 pathway modulates histone H4 in mitochondria to control mtDNA transcription and longevity
Seeking Solar System’s Secrets, NASA’s OSIRIS-REX Mission Touches Bennu Asteroid
Recurrent processing via prefrontal cortex, necessary for quick visual object processing in primates, provides a key insight for developing brain-like artificial intelligence
Lorises use their venom against each other, finds Current Biology study
Beta-Adrenergic Receptor Stimulation Modulates the Cellular Proarrhythmic Effects of Chloroquine and Azithromycin
Limited climate benefits of global recycling of pulp and paper
Providing a hybrid data exploration setup with an AR headset and a regular computer can help data analysis purposes as confirmed by CERN scientists
Retrospective valuation of experienced outcome encoded in distinct reward representations in the anterior insula and amygdala
Wild boar rooting affect spatial distribution of active burrows of meadow-dwelling voles
Recent archaeological excavations on the Peru's south coast provides new evidence of Inka ritual practices that included the dedicatory sacrifice of domesticated animals, such as llamas.
Influence of NAD+ as an ageing-related immunomodulator on COVID-19 infection
Utica Shale Play Oil and Gas Brines: Geochemistry and Factors Influencing Wastewater Management

Stable carbon and nitrogen isotope data of bone collagen of 105 human and 50 animals from the 5th millennium BC to the Sarmatian period indicate dietary variation among the cultural entities as well as regarding age, sex and archaeologically indicated social status is only weakly reflected.

Key details about broadly neutralizing antibodies provide insights for universal flu vaccine: The research is inspired by the limited efficacy of the annual flu vaccine, which must be adjusted each year to provide the best protection against commonly circulating strains of the virus
eNose breath prints as a surrogate biomarker for classifying patients with asthma by atopy. - Abstract
The yeast mating-type switching endonuclease HO is a domesticated member of an unorthodox homing genetic element family
Simulation of high-output and lightweight sliding-mode triboelectric nanogenerators
Spatial ultrasound modulation by digitally controlling microbubble arrays
Enzyme Regulating NAD+ Keeps Mouse Cells Replicating Under Stress
Bridging the Gap Between Biofuels and Biodiversity Through Monetizing Environmental Services of Miscanthus Cultivation
Fasting Drives Nrf2-Related Antioxidant Response in Skeletal Muscle
Researchers from Switzerland recently developed a new approach for generating high-energy, ultrashort pulses with single-mode beam quality: nonlinear beam cleaning in a multimode laser cavity.
Aqueous Film-Forming Foams Exhibit Greater Interfacial Activity than PFOA, PFOS, or FOSA
A Municipal-Scale Analysis of Historic Preservation, Flood Hazards, and Planning
Potential for Powered Flight Neared by Most Close Avialan Relatives, but Few Crossed Its Thresholds
The New Generation Planetary Population Synthesis (NGPPS): III. Warm super-Earths and cold Jupiters: A weak occurrence correlation, but with a strong architecture-composition link
Global burden of disease 👉 204 countries 369 diseases and injuries between 1990–2019.
Lithium-ion capacitor based on nanoarchitectured polydopamine/graphene composite anode and porous graphene cathode
The ecological and evolutionary consequences of systemic racism in urban environments
